New Records: The Blue Jays set a record for their largest shutout victory in franchise history with a 15-0 rout.
Key Match Events: José Berríos pitched six scoreless innings.
Daulton Varsho, Spencer Horwitz, Addison Barger and Will Wagner all homered for the Blue Jays.
Wagner went on to record a five-hit night, becoming the first Blue Jays rookie to do so.
The Blue Jays scored seven runs in the first inning on their way to setting a new season high in runs.
Nathan Lukes had a four-hit night in just his second game of the season with an RBI triple in the ninth inning.
Pre-Game Insights: No one wants to put up zero runs, especially because we were in that ballgame.
Matthews [has] good, good stuff. I thought we kind of took away the top of the zone from him from the get-go, from [Varsho] to Spence.
Post-Match Reflections: It can be tough for professional athletes to maintain their intensity with such a big early lead; Schneider said the roster’s youth made it easier for them to stay locked in.
Berríos was the first to acknowledge that the big cushion provided by the offense helped his confidence on the mound.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Twins starter Zebby Matthews made just his fourth Major League start.
The Blue Jays sent 11 men to the plate in the first; every starter except George Springer had a hit by the second inning.
Every starter -- including Springer -- had scored at least one run by the third inning.
Others: The Twins' starting pitcher, Zebby Matthews, gave up nine runs in just two innings.
The Blue Jays' starting pitcher, José Berríos, was in complete command and cruised through six scoreless innings on just 63 pitches.
